abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Water Supply and
            Sanitation Rehabilitation Project for Sri Lanka was
            unsatisfactory. The project achieved some of its objectives,
            institutional development was negligible, sustainability is
            uncertain, and both the Bank and Borrower performed
            satisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, high quality at entry is necessary since the
            quality of project preparation and appraisal seriously
            affects implementation. Second, the Borrower's
            procurement processes need to be streamlined, and
            NWSDB's capacity to deal with procurement related
            problems needs to be strengthened. Third, donor coordination
            should be improved to better use limited resources and
            ensure that each donor's efforts are consistent with
            the government's long-term sector strategy. Fourth,
            performance based incentive schemes are necessary to retain
            better trained staff and recruit competent technical staff.
            Fifth, training programs should be designed to reorient
            government officials and improve their skills in community
            participation in addition to technical and managerial
            skills. Finally, sector reform is needed to improve
            operational efficiency and meet future challenges.
